questions.question: Approvals vs guardrails — which is the mature stance?
options: Shift routine, low–risk changes to automated guardrails; reserve approvals for high risk
Require approvals for all changes regardless of risk
Eliminate guardrails and rely on manager sign–off
questions.additionalContext: Mature orgs automate safety checks (“policy–as–code”) and retain approvals for novel or high–risk work.

questions.question: Risk assessment inputs emphasized in the article?
options: Impact, likelihood, detectability; consider seasonality and customer segments
questions.additionalContext: Assess impact, likelihood, and detectability; include context like holiday traffic spikes and affected segments.

questions.question: Purpose of change windows?
options: Concentrate staffing/comms when risk appetite is higher; keep emergency windows for true urgent work
questions.additionalContext: Change windows coordinate people and communication for planned risk, while emergency criteria avoid blanket freezes.

questions.question: Communication and audit essentials for significant changes include:
options: Pre–announce timelines/mitigations; keep who/what/when/why in audit trails
questions.additionalContext: Communicate early and maintain auditability: record approvers, rationale, timing, and link to artifacts/incidents.

questions.question: Change Advisory Board (CAB) usage per the article?
options: Use for complex, multi–system changes; avoid for routine reversible work with strong guardrails
questions.additionalContext: CABs help coordinate cross–system change; they are overkill for routine changes where guardrails suffice.

questions.question: What increases safe throughput according to the article?
options: Guardrails enabling smaller, more frequent changes
questions.additionalContext: Smaller, frequent changes with automated checks reduce batch risk and increase safe throughput.

questions.question: Auditability by default means:
options: Collect approvals, evidence, and outcomes in one system; link to monitoring and tickets
questions.additionalContext: Centralize change records with links to PRs, deploys, incidents, RCAs, and monitoring annotations.

questions.question: When replacing approvals with guardrails, teams should:
options: Map risk tiers to guardrails and keep human review for high–impact or irreversible changes
Remove all human review for novel changes
questions.additionalContext: Codify risk tiers and align guardrails/approval paths; preserve human review for high–impact or irreversible changes.

questions.question: Classify a database index addition during peak season. Propose risk tier, guardrails vs approvals, change window, and communication artifacts.
questions.sampleStrongResponse: Risk: medium–high due to peak traffic and potential latency impact. Guardrails: tests, migration dry–run on prod–like data, capacity checks, monitoring annotations, rollback plan. Approvals: domain owner + DBA. Change window: staffed period with on–call ack. Comms: pre–announce internal impact, link to runbook and rollback triggers; update audit record with outcomes.

questions.question: Design an end–to–end change record template that satisfies audit trail essentials and streamlines comms. Include how low–risk changes self–approve when guardrails pass.
questions.sampleStrongResponse: Template fields: what/why, risk tier, guardrails evidence (tests, SLO checks, rollout/rollback plan), approvers (auto–assigned by domain), change window, monitoring annotations, links to PRs/flags/deploys, and outcomes/RCAs. Policy: if risk tier is low and all guardrails pass, auto self–approve with owner ack; otherwise require listed approvers. System auto–publishes comms to stakeholders and stores immutable logs.
